content.text: What a Normal Week Looks Like
Hereâ€™s the thing nobody tells you about being a contractor: most of it is waiting.

The average contractor spends 2-4 days per week on active contract work. The rest is downtime â€” and downtime isnâ€™t vacation. Itâ€™s the time when you manage everything that keeps you alive long enough to take the next contract.

content.label: Daily Routine
content.text: A typical contractor week (no active contract):
items: Morning: Wake up wherever you're sleeping. Check the board â€” scan the contract listings. Most are garbage â€” low-pay, high-risk, or posted by corps you don't trust. You're looking for the ones that match your crew's capabilities.
Midday: Errands. Restock Med Patches. Buy Charges. Check in at the clinic. Visit the market. Every errand costs money. Every errand is an investment in not dying.
Afternoon: Training, crafting, or earning side money. Day-labor (20â€“50 cr/day), skill training (costs AP), workshop time, or market hustling.
Evening: Social. The Watering Hole. Networking isn't optional â€” it's how you learn which contracts are traps and which pay double. Information is survival.
Night: Sleep. Or try to. The quality of your sleep is a direct function of how much money you've invested in not being vulnerable.

content.text: Money In, Money Out
The brutal arithmetic of contractor life:

content.label: Income
content.text: A starting contractor earns 400â€“600 cr per contract. Contracts come every 5â€“10 days if you're active. Call it 500 cr every week, averaged out.
At that rate, a T1 augment (200 cr) takes 1â€“2 weeks of saving. A T3 augment (600 cr) takes a month. A base takes months.

content.label: Crew Savings
content.text: A crew of four sharing expenses saves ~30â€“40%:
items: Shared Capsules or Bunk Room: costs split
Bulk Charges (crafter produces for the team): materials only
Shared vehicle: fuel and maintenance split 4 ways
One Chrome Tech, one medic: installation and treatment free

content.text: Over a campaign, that's the difference between scraping by and actually progressing. This is why crews exist. The math demands it.
The Grind
Thereâ€™s a rhythm to contractor life that every crew discovers:

content.label: The Loop
content.text: The rhythm of contractor life:
items: Week 1â€“2: Contract. Take a job. Go into the rift. Fight things. Harvest materials. Come back. Get paid. Treat your wounds. Rest.
Week 3: Recovery and prep. Spend downtime AP on training, crafting, or healing. Restock supplies. Fix the vehicle. Pay rent.

content.text: This is the loop. Contract, recover, prep, contract. The loop is the game. The tension comes from the things that disrupt the loop: a bad contract that costs more than it pays, a scar that requires expensive treatment, a toxicity spike that forces detox sessions, a vehicle breakdown, a base that needs repairs, a crew member who dies and has to be replaced. Every disruption costs money. Every cost pushes you toward the next contract. The loop tightens.

content.label: Warning
content.text: <strong>The

spiral is real and it's the heart of the game. You need money. You take a contract. The contract gives you scars. Scars need treatment. Treatment costs money. You need money. You take a contract. The contract pushes your toxicity up. Toxicity needs management. Management costs money. You need moneyâ€¦

content.label: Progression
content.text: The only way to break the spiral is investment: a base that eliminates rent, a crafter who eliminates ammo costs, a medic who eliminates treatment costs, augments that make you efficient enough to take higher-paying contracts. Breaking the spiral IS the progression system. It takes the whole campaign.
What Contractors Talk About
At the bar, on the transit, during downtime â€” contractors talk about:
Contracts. Which ones pay. Which ones are traps. Which corps are fair. Which brokers are reliable. Who took the Wellspring live-capture job and whether they came back with all their limbs.

Scars. Everyone has them. Comparing scars is ritual. The stories behind them are currency â€” social currency that establishes your experience, your toughness, and your willingness to do the work. A contractor with no scars is either new, lucky, or lying. A contractor with six scars is either very good or very stubborn.

Money. Always. How much the last job paid. How much rent costs. Whether itâ€™s worth switching to a cheaper district. Whether the team should pool for a vehicle or save for a base. Money talk is constant because money pressure is constant.

The corps. Which ones are hiring. Which ones screwed someone over. Rumors about corporate conflicts that might generate lucrative contracts. Political speculation about which corp is expanding, which is contracting, and what that means for the contract economy.

Toxicity. Quietly. Contractors donâ€™t brag about high toxicity the way they brag about scars. Toxicity is the quiet killer â€” the thing that ends your career not with a dramatic death but with a mandatory quarantine, a corporate harvesting notice, or a mutation that makes you unemployable. Contractors watch each other for signs. The faint glow. The involuntary magic. The moments when someoneâ€™s eyes do something they shouldnâ€™t. Nobody says anything directly. Everyone notices.

Getting out. The dream that nobody believes in but everyone talks about. Save enough money. Buy a place in a free settlement. Retire. Stop going into rifts. Stop accumulating toxicity. Stop collecting scars. Live quietly. Die old. Almost nobody does it. The ones who do are legends. The ones who try and fail are cautionary tales. But the dream persists because the alternative â€” doing this until the rifts or the corps or the toxicity kills you â€” is too bleak to accept without something to aim for.
Contractor Social Strata
Not all contractors are equal. A loose hierarchy exists, acknowledged by everyone, formalized by nobody:

content.title: Fresh Meat
content.subtitle: 0â€“2 scars Â· New to the grind
content.desc: Still figuring out equipment. Still learning to check the board. Still shocked by the prices. Veterans can spot them instantly â€” the gear is too clean, the posture is too confident, and they haven't learned to check corners yet. Most wash out. Some die. The rest become regulars.

content.title: Regulars
content.subtitle: 3â€“5 scars Â· The bulk of contractor society
content.desc: They know the system, they know the margins, they know which corps to trust and which brokers to avoid. A regular contractor is a functioning professional in a profession that tries to kill them. They're good at this. They're also tired.

content.title: Veterans
content.subtitle: 6+ scars Â· Statistical proof of competence
content.desc: Veterans are respected because their survival is statistical proof of competence. They also carry the most toxicity, the most scars, and the most dead friends. There's a weight to them that regulars recognize and fresh meat doesn't understand yet.

content.title: Legends
content.subtitle: Known by name Â· Targeted by everyone

entries.label: Risk
entries.value: Most likely to be targeted by corps, rivals, and IP lawyers

content.desc: Not necessarily the strongest or most augmented â€” sometimes the luckiest, the most connected, or the ones who survived something that should have killed everyone. Legends get offered contracts that aren't on the board. The dream that nobody believes in but everyone talks about.
